Elderson: The human suffering and destruction wrought by the war in Ukraine remains difficult to fathom. It is a stark reminder of the European Union’s core principles – peace in Europe, unity in diversity, shared values and the rule of law

2/2

🧵 Our analytical framework ensures our actions are proportionate to the evidence, says Executive Board member Frank Elderson. We are paving the way for a gradual normalisation with significant policy optionality to account for uncertainty https://t.co/lPdymmbcxY

Firms’ vulnerabilities increased at the start of the pandemic. Although their credit ratings then improved in 2021, they have not yet fully recovered and some concerns linger in parts of the economy https://t.co/NuXhP3qT8h #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/zU0EL9xpst

The economic transformations in the economy that were accelerated by the pandemic could require sound policies to strengthen firms’ finances. Such policies would help to build a strong economic recovery and encourage innovative investment for the green and digital transitions
3/3

Corporate vulnerabilities have decreased. Firms’ revenues increased after pandemic restrictions were eased, making it easier for them to service their debts. But high levels of debt still pose risks to the recovery, particularly in the sectors hardest hit by the pandemic

2/3

🧵Levels of corporate debt rose during the pandemic, but effective policy responses mitigated the negative impact on euro area firms. Insolvencies have declined over the past two years as a result https://t.co/jECt5wG6Rx #EconomicBulletin

1/3 https://t.co/NhdJpOFuBk
Euro area pension fund statistics (Q4 2021) https://t.co/w1AlmKRPqG

Panetta: The clearing ecosystem is evolving quickly as new products, market participants and technologies are made available. 
We need to consider new risks, including those relating to climate change and crypto-assets. 

3/3

Panetta: Financial markets are more stable and resilient when market participants have the option to choose between different central counterparties and when backup arrangements are in place.
The EU can contribute to expanding the availability of clearing options.

2/3

The resilience of central counterparties (CCPs) is crucial in times of crisis, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta. We are closely monitoring volatility in cleared markets linked to Russia’s war in Ukraine.

Speech https://t.co/c3EMMY2kcb

1/3 https://t.co/rJ6m8cC5EJ

The euro area labour market is dynamic, our January 2022 Consumer Expectation Survey shows. 
The unemployment rate has fallen. Moreover, people have changed jobs, expected to earn more and anticipated an improvement in labour markets https://t.co/YELfDIKkJM #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/0BizZvXVd5

De Guindos: We are monitoring inflation developments very closely. If we see second-round effects and a potential de-anchoring of medium-term inflation expectations, then we will act. All options are on the table
3/3

De Guindos: We haven’t yet seen any signs of wage increases being too high and pushing up prices. The same goes for inflation expectations. Inflation, however, is likely to remain higher for longer than was expected before the war
2/3

🧵 The most important decision at our monetary policy meeting was to de-link potential interest rate hikes from asset purchases, says Vice-President Luis de Guindos. We will not necessarily increase interest rates automatically once net purchases end https://t.co/U6V4h06fnP
1/3 https://t.co/zaLCwfrZ3s

A big step towards closing the climate-related data gap.
High-quality data is crucial for assessing the impact of climate change on banks and the economy. This is why gathering reliable data is part of our climate roadmap https://t.co/03UAPKCPuS
See @bundesbank’s press release⬇️ https://t.co/hTVhNzSZOY

The green transition will herald a new age of energy inflation, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. We will continue to protect people’s purchasing power, green our operational framework and work for change in financial markets. 
Read her speech: https://t.co/3KSMn5M7bL https://t.co/zsMhtnLW3X
Working Paper: A narrative database of labour market reforms in euro area economies https://t.co/waPZ3OKmhT

Lagarde: All our monetary policy decisions in the months to come will necessarily be informed by the economic fallout from the war and be data dependent.

Read the full speech https://t.co/z0YKFBXZfJ

3/3

Lagarde: We have begun adjusting policy so that, when the necessary conditions are satisfied, we can take additional steps towards policy normalisation.

We are aware of the underlying risks caused by the war and the uncertainty it is creating in all directions.

2/3

🧵 The challenges facing monetary policy are changing and we are unlikely to return to the same inflation dynamics we saw before the pandemic, says President Christine @Lagarde.

The ECB’s response will be guided by optionality, gradualism and flexibility.

#ECBwatchers

1/3 https://t.co/w3EzZelUy8

As the war in Ukraine rages on, uncertainty about the outlook is increasing, President @Lagarde says at the WELT Economic Summit.

But we still expect the economy to grow robustly in 2022 in our baseline scenario, and inflation to settle around 2% in 2024
 https://t.co/YCSBsytGtz https://t.co/6gpFh3woce

Enria: Banks’ distributions to shareholders should be grounded on bank-specific sound capital planning. Banks should avoid setting dividend policies in absolute amounts. We remain neutral as to whether distributions are made through dividends or share buybacks

3/3

Enria: Banks’ direct exposures to Russia are overall manageable, and the impact of Russian links has been contained so far. Cyber risks are a real threat, although no major disruption has been recorded so far

2/3

Russia’s attack on Ukraine has disrupted the steady improvement in how investors view EU banks, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. Still, given previous restrictions, banks’ planned catch-up with distributions is broadly acceptable
https://t.co/Y0Lss222ms

1/3 https://t.co/L4VD9Pd41r

Given the push for a less complex Stability and Growth Pact in the post-COVID era, this paper assesses a move to a two-tier system based on an expenditure growth rule linked to a debt anchor. This system could help synchronise fiscal and monetary policies https://t.co/z8IFbAEYUO

Banks can and must do much better to improve the quality of their disclosures, and they need to do it quickly, says Supervisory Board Vice-Chair @FrankElderson at the @EBI_EU Policy Series event. Read his speech https://t.co/qlUNruoHnn https://t.co/90lSONioOy

Banks must get better at disclosing climate and environmental risks. They have made progress since our last assessment in 2020, but significant gaps remain. They need to take decisive action.

Lane: The flexibility of our medium-term orientation takes into account that the appropriate response to a deviation of inflation from our 2% target depends on the context, specifically on the origin, magnitude and persistence of the deviation

3/3

Lane: Our medium-term orientation allows for inevitable short-term deviations from our 2% inflation target. It acknowledges that there can be lags and uncertainty in the transmission of monetary policy to the economy and to inflation

2/3

🧵Our strategy is clear – We will set monetary policy to ensure that inflation stabilises at 2% over the medium term, says Chief Economist Philip R. Lane. It provides a playbook for our monetary policy decisions and for handling a variety of scenarios https://t.co/FdL9NvDTbI

1/3 https://t.co/EFtWislgmF

Euro area insurance company investment funds grew by 6.5% in 2021, accounting for 30% of their total asset. Despite companies making net sales of over €30 billion, debt securities remained the main investment instrument in 2021. Read our press release https://t.co/XGoLFjeEVY https://t.co/FAIv6PAA5p

Supervisory independence and accountability are two sides of the same coin, says Supervisory Board member Kerstin af Jochnick. Clear institutional mandates and sound accountability support effective banking supervision https://t.co/BsQtg7StSo https://t.co/0aXPagKBvG
Euro money market statistics (8th maintenance period 2021) https://t.co/o6SkkHHULP

Panetta: We stand ready to act to avoid any dislocation in financial markets that could stem from the war in Ukraine and to protect the transmission of monetary policy. 
We stand by the people of Ukraine and will swiftly implement the sanctions decided on by the EU. 

3/3

Panetta: Given the conflict in Ukraine, we face greater financial volatility in the short term and macroeconomic uncertainty in the medium term. 
It would be unwise to pre-commit on future policy steps until the fallout from the current crisis becomes clearer. 

2/3

🧵Confronted with supply shocks that are both inflationary and contractionary, we should adjust our policy moderately and progressively as we receive feedback on the effects of our actions, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta. 

Speech https://t.co/LqyscA0kSR

1/3 https://t.co/e3OjoDxw2B
